Abstract ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic 111-motives and Tate‚Äôs canonical class for number fields

Cornelius Greither and Cristian D. Popescu Institut f√ºr Theoretische Informatik und Mathematik, Universit√§t der Bundeswehr, M√ºnchen, 85577 Neubiberg, Germany cornelius.greither@unibw.de Department of Mathematics, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093-0112, USA cpopescu@math.ucsd.edu
Abstract.

In [GP2] we constructed a new class of Iwasawa modules as ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic realizations of what we called abstract ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic 111‚Äìmotives in the number field setting. We proved in loc. cit. that the new Iwasawa modules satisfy an equivariant main conjecture. In this paper we link the new modules to the ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadified Tate canonical class, defined by Tate in 1960 [Ta1] and give an explicit construction of (the minus part of) ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic Tate sequences for any Galois CM extension K/kùêæùëòK/k of an arbitrary totally real number field kùëòk. These explicit constructions are significant and useful in their own right but also due to their applications (via results in [GP2]) to a proof of the minus part of the far reaching Equivariant Tamagawa Number Conjecture for the Artin motive associated to the Galois extension K/kùêæùëòK/k.

Key words and phrases:
Iwasawa theory; Galois module structure; Tate sequences; √âtale cohomology.

11R23, 11R34, 11R33, 11R42, 11R70, 14G40

1. Setup and preparation

Let K/kùêæùëòK/k be a Galois extension of number fields of Galois group Gùê∫G. Assume that KùêæK is a CM field and that kùëòk is totally real. We fix an odd prime ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell and denote by K‚àûsubscriptùêæK_{\infty} and k‚àûsubscriptùëòk_{\infty} the cyclotomic ‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}‚Äìextensions of KùêæK and kùëòk, respectively. We fix two finite, disjoint, Gùê∫G‚Äìinvariant sets of primes SùëÜS and TùëáT in KùêæK, such that SùëÜS contains the ramification locus Sram‚Äã(K‚àû/k)subscriptùëÜramsubscriptùêæùëòS_{\rm ram}(K_{\infty}/k) of K‚àû/ksubscriptùêæùëòK_{\infty}/k (in particular, it contains the set S‚ÑìsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìS_{\ell} of all ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic primes and the set S‚àûsubscriptùëÜS_{\infty} of all the archimedean primes) and TùëáT contains at least two primes of distinct residual characteristics. We assume throughout that the classical Iwasawa Œºùúá\mu‚Äìinvariant associated to K‚àûsubscriptùêæK_{\infty} and ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell vanishes, as conjectured by Iwasawa.

In earlier work [GP2] we defined the category of ‚Äúabstract ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic 111‚Äìmotives‚Äù (which contains Deligne‚Äôs category of Picard 111‚Äìmotives as a full subcategory) and from the data (K/k,S,T,‚Ñì)ùêæùëòùëÜùëá‚Ñì(K/k,S,T,\ell) as above we constructed a canonical abstract ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic 111‚Äìmotive ‚Ñ≥:=‚Ñ≥S,T‚Ñì‚Äã(K/k)assign‚Ñ≥superscriptsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëÜùëá‚Ñìùêæùëò\mathcal{M}:=\mathcal{M}_{S,T}^{\ell}(K/k). Its ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic realization (Tate module) T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}) which was defined in loc.cit. is a free ‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}‚Äìmodule of finite rank which comes endowed with a natural ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[[ùí¢]]subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]delimited-[]ùí¢\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[[\mathcal{G}]]‚Äìmodule structure, where ùí¢:=Gal‚Äã(K‚àû/k)assignùí¢Galsubscriptùêæùëò\mathcal{G}:={\rm Gal}(K_{\infty}/k). Remark 1.2.

In [GP1] we proved the exact analogue of Theorem 1.1 in the case where K/kùêæùëòK/k is a Galois extension of global fields of characteristic p>0ùëù0p>0 (i.e. function fields) and K‚àûsubscriptùêæK_{\infty} (respectively k‚àûsubscriptùëòk_{\infty}) is the maximal constant field extension of KùêæK (respectively kùëòk.) In that geometric context there is no analogue of complex conjugation, so taking (‚àí1)1(-1)‚Äìeigenspaces does not make sense. Also, there is no analogue of the sets S‚ÑìsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìS_{\ell} or S‚àûsubscriptùëÜS_{\infty} and, most importantly, the extension K‚àû/KsubscriptùêæùêæK_{\infty}/K (which in that case is the maximal constant field extension of KùêæK) is unramified.

The remark above makes it easier for us to state the goals of this paper more precisely: prove (1) and (3) in the number field setting laid out above, under the assumption that ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell is an odd prime, with US,T‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñìtensor-productsubscriptùëàùëÜùëásubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìU_{S,T}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}, XS‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñìtensor-productsubscriptùëãùëÜsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìX_{S}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell} and œÑK/k,S‚ÑìsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùêæùëòùëÜ‚Ñì\tau_{K/k,S}^{\ell} replaced by (US,T‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àísuperscripttensor-productsubscriptùëàùëÜùëásubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì(U_{S,T}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{-}, (XS‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àísuperscripttensor-productsubscriptùëãùëÜsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì(X_{S}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{-} and œÑK/k,S,T‚Ñì,‚àísuperscriptsubscriptùúèùêæùëòùëÜùëá‚Ñì\tau_{K/k,S,T}^{\ell,\,-}, respectively.

As in [GPff], we will approach the question of linking C‚àôsuperscriptùê∂‚àôC^{\bullet} to the Tate class from two sides. On one hand we calculate the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìinvariants and ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìcoinvariants of T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}) directly, via Iwasawa theoretic methods, in sections 2 and 3. On the other hand, in section 5 (see Theorem 5.9) we establish the desired link between C‚àôsuperscriptùê∂‚àôC^{\bullet} and the Tate class œÑK/k,S‚Ñì,‚àísuperscriptsubscriptùúèùêæùëòùëÜ‚Ñì\tau_{K/k,S}^{\ell,-} via calculations in a certain derived category and by relying in an essential way upon deep results of Burns‚ÄìFlach [BF] and [Bu1]. The reason why we insist on presenting the explicit calculations of the cohomology of C‚àôsuperscriptùê∂‚àôC^{\bullet} is because the proof of Theorem 5.9 relies on less explicit, not so easily transparent derived category arguments. It is satisfactory to see that the results obtained via the two approaches agree at the cohomology level. We must admit that at present the explicit calculation in the coinvariant case is somewhat laborious and not as smooth as the result one extracts from the ‚Äúidentification‚Äù with Tate‚Äôs canonical class. However, it is definitely much more explicit.

The rest of this section reviews additional notation and presents some preparations.

For the construction of ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M} and its ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìadic realization T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}), the reader should consult [GP2]. For the definition of Tate‚Äôs class œÑK/k,SsubscriptùúèùêæùëòùëÜ\tau_{K/k,S} the reader should consult [Ta1, Ta2]. In order to simplify notation we will let ùí¶:=K‚àûassignùí¶subscriptùêæ\mathcal{K}:=K_{\infty}. For any algebraic field extension N/KùëÅùêæN/K, S‚Äã(N)ùëÜùëÅS(N) denotes the set of places of NùëÅN above places in SùëÜS, but often we will be sloppy in context, just writing SùëÜS instead of S‚Äã(N)ùëÜùëÅS(N). In the particular case N=ùí¶ùëÅùí¶N=\mathcal{K} we write ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S} for S‚Äã(ùí¶)ùëÜùí¶S(\mathcal{K}). The same notational convention should be used for the set TùëáT, but for simplicity we will use TùëáT for T‚Äã(N)ùëáùëÅT(N) and for ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} most of the time. No confusion will ensue. The superscript minus always means the (‚àí1)1(-1)-eigenspace under the unique complex conjugation of ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K}, as customary. 2. Invariants

We begin by dealing with the ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants. This is a relatively easy task in light of a very concrete interpretation given to T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}) in [GP2], ¬ß3. In this section and the next, we make two blanket assumptions:

  • (1)

    SùëÜS is ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell‚Äìlarge, i.e. CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K) is generated by the classes of primes in SùëÜS.

The second assumption will be eliminated in section 4 below.

3. Coinvariants

Now, we turn to the calculation of ŒìŒì\Gamma-coinvariants of T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}). We remind the reader that the assumptions (1) and (2), see beginning of Section 2, are in force. The desired isomorphism T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚âÖ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S]‚àísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥Œìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜT_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma}\cong\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S]^{-} will result via a simple homological algebra lemma (Lemma 3.8) from Thm.¬†3.4 (ii) below which yields a short exact sequence

0‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Ñì]‚àí‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àí‚Üí0.‚Üí0subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëÜ‚Ñì‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥Œì‚Üísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì‚Üí00\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S_{\ell}]^{-}\to T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma}\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-}\to 0.

Unfortunately there does not seem to be a simple proof of the existence of this sequence. We begin with some notation and some fairly easy auxiliary results. Then we present the calculation of the coinvariants modulo three lemmas (one of which is highly technical), and finally we proceed to prove the lemmas.

Let KnsubscriptùêæùëõK_{n} be the unique intermediate field of ùí¶/Kùí¶ùêæ\mathcal{K}/K with [Kn:K]=‚Ñìn[K_{n}:K]=\ell^{n}. Let Œìn=Gal‚Äã(Kn/K)subscriptŒìùëõGalsubscriptùêæùëõùêæ\Gamma_{n}={\rm Gal}(K_{n}/K) and let Œ≥n‚ààŒìnsubscriptùõæùëõsubscriptŒìùëõ\gamma_{n}\in\Gamma_{n} be the image of the generator Œ≥ùõæ\gamma of ŒìŒì\Gamma via Galois restriction. Let dùëëd be the ‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}-rank of ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Ñì]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëÜ‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S_{\ell}]^{-} (note that this is unchanged if S‚ÑìsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìS_{\ell} is replaced by S‚Ñì‚Äã(Kn)subscriptùëÜ‚ÑìsubscriptùêæùëõS_{\ell}(K_{n}) or ùíÆ‚ÑìsubscriptùíÆ‚Ñì\mathcal{S}_{\ell} due to our blanket hypotheses).

We remind the reader that CT‚Äã(N)superscriptùê∂ùëáùëÅC^{T}(N) (respectively C‚Äã(N)ùê∂ùëÅC(N)) is shorthand for the minus part of the ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-part of the ray class group c‚ÄãlT‚Äã(N)ùëêsubscriptùëôùëáùëÅcl_{T}(N) (respectively class group c‚Äãl‚Äã(N)ùëêùëôùëÅcl(N)), for any appropriate field NùëÅN. (Usually NùëÅN is one of the fields KnsubscriptùêæùëõK_{n}.) It is well known (see [GP2], for example) that the canonical maps CT‚Äã(Kn)‚ÜíCT‚Äã(Kn+1)‚Üísuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõ1C^{T}(K_{n})\to C^{T}(K_{n+1}) and C‚Äã(Kn)‚ÜíC‚Äã(Kn+1)‚Üíùê∂subscriptùêæùëõùê∂subscriptùêæùëõ1C(K_{n})\to C(K_{n+1}) are injective and that C‚àûT=‚ãÉnCT‚Äã(Kn)subscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùëõsubscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõC^{T}_{\infty}=\bigcup_{n}C_{T}(K_{n}) and C‚àû=‚ãÉnC‚Äã(Kn)subscriptùê∂subscriptùëõùê∂subscriptùêæùëõC_{\infty}=\bigcup_{n}C(K_{n}).

Let DT‚Äã(N)‚äÇCT‚Äã(N)superscriptùê∑ùëáùëÅsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùëÅD^{T}(N)\subset C^{T}(N) be the subgroup generated by the classes of the prime ideals in NùëÅN dividing ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. It is easy to see that

‚à£Im‚Äã(DT‚Äã(N)‚ÜíCT‚Äã(Kn)/CT‚Äã(K))‚à£‚â§‚Ñìn‚Äãd.delimited-‚à£‚à£Im‚Üísuperscriptùê∑ùëáùëÅsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsuperscript‚Ñìùëõùëë\mid{\rm Im}\Bigl{(}D^{T}(N)\to\,C^{T}(K_{n})/C^{T}(K)\Bigr{)}\mid\,\leq\ell^{nd}.

Note that it is legitimate to consider CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K) as a subgroup of CT‚Äã(Kn)superscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõC^{T}(K_{n}).

Lemma 3.1.

The preceding inequality is an equality, that is:

‚à£Im‚Äã(DT‚Äã(N)‚ÜíCT‚Äã(Kn)/CT‚Äã(K))‚à£=‚Ñìn‚Äãd,for all¬†n.delimited-‚à£‚à£Im‚Üísuperscriptùê∑ùëáùëÅsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsuperscript‚Ñìùëõùëëfor all¬†n.\mid{\rm Im}\Bigl{(}D^{T}(N)\to\,C^{T}(K_{n})/C^{T}(K)\Bigr{)}\mid\,=\ell^{nd},\quad\text{for all $n$.}

Proof: Let b1,‚Ä¶,bdsubscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëëb_{1},\ldots,b_{d} be a ‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}‚Äìbasis of ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Ñì‚Äã(Kn)]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëÜ‚Ñìsubscriptùêæùëõ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S_{\ell}(K_{n})]^{-} where each bisubscriptùëèùëñb_{i} has the form (1‚àíj)‚Äãùî≠1ùëóùî≠(1-j)\mathfrak{p} for some prime ùî≠|‚Ñìconditionalùî≠‚Ñì\mathfrak{p}|\ell in KnsubscriptùêæùëõK_{n}. (The letter jùëój means complex conjugation of course; we have to take exactly those ùî≠ùî≠\mathfrak{p} that split from K+superscriptùêæK^{+} to KùêæK.) There is a map

œÜnT:(‚Ñ§/‚Ñìn)d‚ÜíCT‚Äã(Kn)/CT‚Äã(K):superscriptsubscriptùúëùëõùëá‚Üísuperscript‚Ñ§superscript‚Ñìùëõùëësuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæ\varphi_{n}^{T}:(\mathbb{Z}/\ell^{n})^{d}\to C^{T}(K_{n})/C^{T}(K)

sending the iùëñi-th basis vector eisubscriptùëíùëñe_{i} of the left-hand module to the class of bisubscriptùëèùëñb_{i}. It is well-defined since ‚Ñìn‚Äãbisuperscript‚Ñìùëõsubscriptùëèùëñ\ell^{n}b_{i} comes from an ideal of KùêæK. The image of œÜnTsuperscriptsubscriptùúëùëõùëá\varphi_{n}^{T} is equal to the image of DT‚Äã(Kn)superscriptùê∑ùëásubscriptùêæùëõD^{T}(K_{n}) in CT‚Äã(Kn)/CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K_{n})/C^{T}(K). We claim that œÜnTsuperscriptsubscriptùúëùëõùëá\varphi_{n}^{T} is injective. For this it clearly suffices to show the injectivity of the analogously defined map

œÜn:(‚Ñ§/‚Ñìn)d‚ÜíC‚Äã(Kn)/C‚Äã(K),:subscriptùúëùëõ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñ§superscript‚Ñìùëõùëëùê∂subscriptùêæùëõùê∂ùêæ\varphi_{n}:(\mathbb{Z}/\ell^{n})^{d}\to C(K_{n})/C(K),

as œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} factors through œÜnTsuperscriptsubscriptùúëùëõùëá\varphi_{n}^{T}. Let (m1,‚Ä¶,md)‚àà‚Ñ§dsubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëësuperscript‚Ñ§ùëë(m_{1},\ldots,m_{d})\in\mathbb{Z}^{d} and assume that the class [‚àèibimi]delimited-[]subscriptproductùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëñsubscriptùëöùëñ[\prod_{i}b_{i}^{m_{i}}] in C‚Äã(Kn)ùê∂subscriptùêæùëõC(K_{n}) is equal to [ùî†]delimited-[]ùî†[\mathfrak{c}] where ùî†ùî†\mathfrak{c} is a fractional ideal in KùêæK. This means that there exists x‚àà(Kn√ó‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àíùë•superscripttensor-productsuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìx\in({K_{n}^{\times}}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{-} such that divKn‚Äã(x)=‚àíùî†+‚àëimi‚ãÖbisubscriptdivsubscriptùêæùëõùë•ùî†subscriptùëñ‚ãÖsubscriptùëöùëñsubscriptùëèùëñ{\rm div}_{K_{n}}(x)=-\mathfrak{c}+\sum_{i}m_{i}\cdot b_{i}. Since the module of roots of unity Œº‚Äã(Kn)ùúásubscriptùêæùëõ\mu(K_{n}) is ŒìnsubscriptŒìùëõ\Gamma_{n}-cohomologically trivial (well known fact), we may arrange that xŒ≥n‚àí1=1superscriptùë•subscriptùõæùëõ11x^{\gamma_{n}-1}=1, that is xùë•x is already in K√ó‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñìtensor-productsuperscriptùêæsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìK^{\times}\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}. Then the divisor ‚àëimi‚ãÖbisubscriptùëñ‚ãÖsubscriptùëöùëñsubscriptùëèùëñ\sum_{i}m_{i}\cdot b_{i} also comes from KùêæK, and this is only possible if all misubscriptùëöùëñm_{i} are divisible by ‚Ñìnsuperscript‚Ñìùëõ\ell^{n} (remember that all primes above ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell in KnsubscriptùêæùëõK_{n} are totally ramified in Kn/KsubscriptùêæùëõùêæK_{n}/K). This shows that œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} is injective as claimed. ¬†Q.E.D.

Recall that C‚àûT=‚ãÉnCT‚Äã(Kn)subscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùêæùëõC^{T}_{\infty}=\bigcup_{n}C^{T}(K_{n}). Define D‚àûT:=‚ãÉnDT‚Äã(Kn)assignsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëásubscriptùëõsuperscriptùê∑ùëásubscriptùêæùëõD^{T}_{\infty}:=\bigcup_{n}D^{T}(K_{n}).

Lemma 3.2.

(i) (C‚àûT)Œì=CT‚Äã(K)‚ãÖD‚àûTsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëáŒì‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëá(C^{T}_{\infty})^{\Gamma}=C^{T}(K)\cdot D^{T}_{\infty}, and D‚àûTsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëáD^{T}_{\infty} is divisible.

(ii) D‚àûTsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëáD^{T}_{\infty} is the divisible part of (C‚àûT)Œìsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëáŒì(C^{T}_{\infty})^{\Gamma}.

(iii) We have D‚àûT‚à©CT‚Äã(K)=DT‚Äã(K)subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëásuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsuperscriptùê∑ùëáùêæD^{T}_{\infty}\cap C^{T}(K)=D^{T}(K).

Proof: (i) We start with the ‚Äúambiguous class number formula‚Äù, both for Kn/KsubscriptùêæùëõùêæK_{n}/K and for Kn+/K+superscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùêæK_{n}^{+}/K^{+}, see Lemma 13.4.1 in [La]. If we divide the former by the latter and note that the second factor in the denominator in loc.cit. just goes away in the minus part (again, cohomological triviality of roots of unity), we end up, after some comparison of notation, with the following:

|C‚Äã(Kn)Œìn|=|C‚Äã(K)|‚ãÖ‚Ñìn‚Äãd.ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsubscriptŒìùëõ‚ãÖùê∂ùêæsuperscript‚Ñìùëõùëë|C(K_{n})^{\Gamma_{n}}|=|C(K)|\cdot\ell^{nd}.

It is a straightforward exercice to deduce from this the following TùëáT-variant:

|CT‚Äã(Kn)Œìn|=|CT‚Äã(K)|‚ãÖ‚Ñìn‚Äãd.superscriptùê∂ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsubscriptŒìùëõ‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsuperscript‚Ñìùëõùëë|C^{T}(K_{n})^{\Gamma_{n}}|=|C^{T}(K)|\cdot\ell^{nd}.

When combined with the previous Lemma (and its proof) the above equality implies that the natural map DT‚Äã(Kn)‚ÜíCT‚Äã(Kn)Œìn/CT‚Äã(K)‚Üísubscriptùê∑ùëásubscriptùêæùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsubscriptŒìùëõsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæD_{T}(K_{n})\to C^{T}(K_{n})^{\Gamma_{n}}/C^{T}(K) is bijective. Therefore we obtain

CT‚Äã(Kn)Œìn=CT‚Äã(K)‚ãÖDT‚Äã(Kn).superscriptùê∂ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëõsubscriptŒìùëõ‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsuperscriptùê∑ùëásubscriptùêæùëõC^{T}(K_{n})^{\Gamma_{n}}=C^{T}(K)\cdot D^{T}(K_{n}).

By passing to the inductive limit, we obtain

(C‚àûT)Œì=CT‚Äã(K)‚ãÖD‚àûT.superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëáŒì‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∂ùëáùêæsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëá(C^{T}_{\infty})^{\Gamma}=C^{T}(K)\cdot D^{T}_{\infty}.

This proves the equality in (i). Now, D‚àûTsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëáD^{T}_{\infty} is divisible since all ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-adic primes are infinitely ramified in K‚àû/KsubscriptùêæùêæK_{\infty}/K. Since CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K) is finite, we get (ii) at once.

Part (iii) is proved using the method of proof of the preceding lemma: any element of D‚àûTsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëáD^{T}_{\infty} fixed by Œì=Œì0ŒìsubscriptŒì0\Gamma=\Gamma_{0} has to come from an ideal of KùêæK supported above ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. ¬†Q.E.D.


We now present the initial step towards calculating the coinvariants. We need one more object. Let BT‚Äã(K)superscriptùêµùëáùêæB^{T}(K) denote the quotient of CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K) by the subgroup DT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∑ùëáùêæD^{T}(K).

Proposition 3.3.

There is an exact sequence

0‚ÜíBT‚Äã(K)‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àûT)Œì‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àí‚Üí0.‚Üí0superscriptùêµùëáùêæ‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëáŒì‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥Œì‚Üísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì‚Üí00\to B^{T}(K)\to T_{\ell}(C^{T}_{\infty})_{\Gamma}\to T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma}\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-}\to 0.

Proof: We extract the following sequence from the diagram at the end of Section 1 (the second arrow is the snake map):

T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[ùíÆ‚àñùíÆ‚Ñì]‚àí,Œì‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àûT)Œì‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[ùíÆ‚àñùíÆ‚Ñì]Œì‚àí‚Üí0.‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsuperscript‚Ñ≥Œìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùíÆsubscriptùíÆ‚ÑìŒì‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëáŒì‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥Œì‚Üísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùíÆsubscriptùíÆ‚ÑìŒì‚Üí0T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})^{\Gamma}\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[\mathcal{S}\setminus\mathcal{S}_{\ell}]^{-,\Gamma}\to T_{\ell}(C^{T}_{\infty})_{\Gamma}\to T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma}\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[\mathcal{S}\setminus\mathcal{S}_{\ell}]^{-}_{\Gamma}\to 0.

The second and last nontrivial terms are isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-} (as primes in S‚àñS‚ÑìùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìS\setminus S_{\ell} are not ramified in K‚àû/KsubscriptùêæùêæK_{\infty}/K.) Going back to the proof of Proposition 2.1, one may verify the following: if we identify T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œìsubscriptùëá‚Ñìsuperscript‚Ñ≥ŒìT_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})^{\Gamma} with (‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚äóUS,T)‚àísuperscripttensor-productsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìsubscriptùëàùëÜùëá(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\otimes U_{S,T})^{-} as in loc.cit, then the first arrow T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œì‚Üí‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àí‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsuperscript‚Ñ≥Œìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìT_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})^{\Gamma}\to\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-} corresponds to the S‚ÑìsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìS_{\ell}‚Äìforgetful divisor map divK,S‚àñS‚ÑìsubscriptdivùêæùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì{\rm div}_{K,S\setminus S_{\ell}} from (‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚äó‚Ñ§US,T)‚àísuperscriptsubscripttensor-product‚Ñ§subscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìsubscriptùëàùëÜùëá(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}}U_{S,T})^{-} to ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-}. Proof of of Thm.¬†3.4 part (iii): This would follow immediately if we could prove that the short exact sequence in Thm.¬†3.4(ii) is split. This is indeed the case, as shown by the next lemma.

Lemma 3.8.

Then the Ext group Ext‚Ñ§‚Äã[G]1‚Å°(‚Ñ§‚Äã[G/U],‚Ñ§‚Äã[G/V])subscriptsuperscriptExt1‚Ñ§delimited-[]ùê∫‚Ñ§delimited-[]ùê∫ùëà‚Ñ§delimited-[]ùê∫ùëâ\operatorname{Ext}^{1}_{\mathbb{Z}[G]}(\mathbb{Z}[G/U],\mathbb{Z}[G/V]) vanishes. (Our modules are left modules, so G/Uùê∫ùëàG/U denotes the set of left cosets x‚ÄãUùë•ùëàxU, with the obvious Gùê∫G-action.) Consequently Ext‚Ñ§‚Äã[G]1‚Å°(M,N)subscriptsuperscriptExt1‚Ñ§delimited-[]ùê∫ùëÄùëÅ\operatorname{Ext}^{1}_{\mathbb{Z}[G]}(M,N) vanishes for any two permutation modules MùëÄM and NùëÅN, and this holds as well if the base ring ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z} is replaced by ‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}.

Proof of of Lemma 3.8: The proof is an exercise in permutation modules. We leave it to the reader. ¬†Q.E.D.

The preceding Lemma applies in particular to the permutation modules N=‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Ñì]‚àíùëÅsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëÜ‚ÑìN=\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S_{\ell}]^{-} and M=‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àñS‚Ñì]‚àíùëÄsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚ÑìM=\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S\setminus S_{\ell}]^{-}: the exact sequence in Thm.¬†3.4 (ii) is split, and the module in the middle is therefore isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S]^{-}. ¬†Q.E.D.

Remark 3.9.

Let us remark that we do not quite get an explicit isomorphism between T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œìsubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥ŒìT_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma} and ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S]^{-}. It is explicit up to a splitting of an exact sequence, which exists but is not unique. Unfortunately, although the final theorem in the next section does also imply, as a corollary, that T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)Œìsubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥ŒìT_{\ell}(\mathcal{M})_{\Gamma} is indeed isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S]^{-}, since the ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-adified Tate sequence in the minus part has exactly ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S]^{-} on the right, that isomorphism is much less explicit.

4. Removing a technical assumption

In this short section we explain how to eliminate condition (2) (see Section 2) in the end results of the preceding two sections. (Condition (1) is built into the theory of Tate sequences and therefore indispensable.) The idea is the same for invariants and for coinvariants. One chooses n0subscriptùëõ0n_{0} large enough so that condition (2) holds for K‚àû/Kn0subscriptùêæsubscriptùêæsubscriptùëõ0K_{\infty}/K_{n_{0}} and puts Œì0=Gal‚Å°(K‚àû/Kn0)subscriptŒì0Galsubscriptùêæsubscriptùêæsubscriptùëõ0\Gamma_{0}=\operatorname{Gal}(K_{\infty}/K_{n_{0}}). If we replace KùêæK by K0subscriptùêæ0K_{0} in the results Prop.¬†2.1 and Thm.¬†3.4 (ii) (jointly with Lemma 3.8, we obtain descriptions of T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥Œì0)subscriptùëá‚Ñìsuperscript‚Ñ≥subscriptŒì0T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}^{\Gamma_{0}}) and T‚Ñì‚Äã(MŒì0)subscriptùëá‚ÑìsubscriptùëÄsubscriptŒì0T_{\ell}(M_{\Gamma_{0}}); the isomorphisms in these descriptions are invariant under G‚Ä≤:=G√ó(Œì/Œì0)assignsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤ùê∫ŒìsubscriptŒì0G^{\prime}:=G\times(\Gamma/\Gamma_{0}). We then perform a final (co)descent, taking invariants (resp.¬†coinvariants) under the action Œì/Œì0ŒìsubscriptŒì0\Gamma/\Gamma_{0}. For the invariants everything is clear: the Œì/Œì0ŒìsubscriptŒì0\Gamma/\Gamma_{0}-invariants of (US,T‚Äã(Kn0)‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àísuperscripttensor-productsubscriptùëàùëÜùëásubscriptùêæsubscriptùëõ0subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì(U_{S,T}(K_{n_{0}})\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{-} coincide with (US,T‚Äã(K)‚äó‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àísuperscripttensor-productsubscriptùëàùëÜùëáùêæsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì(U_{S,T}(K)\otimes\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{-}. For the coinvariants, it is also easy to check that ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Äã(Kn0)]Œì/Œì0‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùêæsubscriptùëõ0ŒìsubscriptŒì0\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S(K_{n_{0}})]^{-}_{\Gamma/\Gamma_{0}} is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚Äã(K)]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜùêæ\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S(K)]^{-}. The resulting isomorphism at level KùêæK is, of course, not quite explicit, since the isomorphism at level Kn0subscriptùêæsubscriptùëõ0K_{n_{0}}, coming about through Lemma 3.8, was not totally explicit.

Proposition 5.3.

There is an isomorphism in Dperf‚Äã(‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G])superscriptùê∑perfsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]ùê∫D^{\mbox{\tiny perf}}(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G])

(‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚äó‚Ñ§œÑ)‚Äã[‚àí1]‚âÖR‚ÄãŒì‚Äã(X,‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã(1)).subscripttensor-product‚Ñ§subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìùúèdelimited-[]1ùëÖŒìùëãsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì1(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}}\tau)[-1]\cong R\Gamma(X,\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}(1)).

(The [‚àí1]delimited-[]1[-1]‚Äìshift on the left produces a complex with cohomology concentrated in degrees 1 and 2.)

Proof: This is a fairly short argument. All the same, it is not very direct, since it uses the full strength of the key paper [BF]. Unexplained notation is taken literally from there; all references in the present proof are to this paper, if not said otherwise.

According to the last line of p.1383, the complex Œ®SsubscriptŒ®ùëÜ\Psi_{S} represents Tate‚Äôs class œÑùúè\tau (see the definition of KSsubscriptùêæùëÜK_{S}, p.1351 and p.1353). By Prop.¬†3.3, we have an isomorphism in the derived category (of course one also has to check, using the explicit information given in loc.cit. eqn.(69) that it gives the canonical maps on cohomology):

‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚äóœÑ‚âÖR‚ÄãŒìc‚Äã(X,‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àó‚Äã[‚àí2].tensor-productsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìùúèùëÖsubscriptŒìùëêsuperscriptùëãsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]2\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\otimes\tau\cong R\Gamma_{c}(X,\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{*}[-2].

The superscript star stands for R‚ÄãHom‚Å°(‚àí,‚Ñ§‚Ñì)ùëÖHomsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìR\,\operatorname{Hom}(-,\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}) (a functor of the derived category to itself). Now we invoke Lemma 16(b), which gives

R‚ÄãŒìc‚Äã(X,‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚àó‚âÖR‚ÄãŒìc‚Äã(X,‚Ñö‚Ñì/‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚à®,ùëÖsubscriptŒìùëêsuperscriptùëãsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìùëÖsubscriptŒìùëêsuperscriptùëãsubscript‚Ñö‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìR\Gamma_{c}(X,\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{*}\cong R\Gamma_{c}(X,\mathbb{Q}_{\ell}/\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{\vee},

where the superscript ‚à®\vee is R‚ÄãHom‚Å°(‚àí,‚Ñö‚Ñì/‚Ñ§‚Ñì)ùëÖHomsubscript‚Ñö‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚ÑìR\operatorname{Hom}(-,\mathbb{Q}_{\ell}/\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}). In contrast to the functor ()‚àósuperscript()^{*}, the functor ‚à®\vee can be evaluated on any complex in a quasi-isomorphism class, termwise, since Hom‚Å°(‚àí,‚Ñö‚Ñì/‚Ñ§‚Ñì)Homsubscript‚Ñö‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì\operatorname{Hom}(-,\mathbb{Q}_{\ell}/\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}) is exact. As a third and last ingredient, we invoke Artin-Verdier duality:

R‚ÄãŒìc‚Äã(X,‚Ñö‚Ñì/‚Ñ§‚Ñì)‚à®‚Äã[‚àí3]‚âÖR‚ÄãŒì‚Äã(X,‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã(1)).ùëÖsubscriptŒìùëêsuperscriptùëãsubscript‚Ñö‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]3ùëÖŒìùëãsubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì1R\Gamma_{c}(X,\mathbb{Q}_{\ell}/\mathbb{Z}_{\ell})^{\vee}[-3]\cong R\Gamma(X,\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}(1)).

Again one has to make sure that the two preceding isomorphisms are canonical on cohomology level. Putting the three displayed isomorphisms together (the first shifted by ‚àí11-1, and the second by ‚àí33-3), we obtain the formula of the proposition. Note: We have been following the sign conventions of [BF]. It appears that in the terminology of [Bu1], a minus sign would come up. ¬†Q. E. D.


Another important step is a description of T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}) in terms of √©tale cohomology. We intend to establish the following result.

(See the proof of Proposition 2.1 and the notations therein.)

Proposition 5.5.

For any fixed mùëöm as above, there is a natural isomorphism

œÜ=œÜm:ùí¶ùíÆ,T(m)/ùí¶T√óm‚Äã‚ü∂‚àº‚ÄãH1‚Å°(ùí≥,j!‚Äã‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)).:ùúësubscriptùúëùëösubscriptsuperscriptùí¶ùëöùíÆùëásuperscriptsubscriptùí¶ùëáabsentùëösimilar-to‚ü∂superscriptH1ùí≥subscriptùëó‚Ñ§ùëö1\varphi=\varphi_{m}:{\mathcal{K}}^{(m)}_{\mathcal{S},T}/\mathcal{K}_{T}^{\times m}\overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{H}^{1}(\mathcal{X},j_{!}\mathbb{Z}/m(1)).

Proof: This will take several steps. Most of the underlying ideas are from [De], see Section 10.3.6 in particular, but the mathematical language in loc.cit. is so different that we prefer to give a reasonably self-contained argument.

To make the main points more clearly visible, we will first prove a simplified version: replace TùëáT by the empty set. (In particular, j!‚Äã‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)subscriptùëó‚Ñ§ùëö1j_{!}\mathbb{Z}/m(1) just becomes ‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)‚Ñ§ùëö1\mathbb{Z}/m(1).) is an isomorphism. The equivalence relation is as expected: (‚Ñí,Œ±)‚àº(‚Ñí‚Ä≤,Œ±‚Ä≤)similar-to‚Ñíùõºsuperscript‚Ñí‚Ä≤superscriptùõº‚Ä≤(\mathcal{L},\alpha)\sim(\mathcal{L}^{\prime},\alpha^{\prime}) iff there is an isomorphism h:‚Ñí‚Üí‚Ñí‚Ä≤:‚Ñé‚Üí‚Ñísuperscript‚Ñí‚Ä≤h:\mathcal{L}\to\mathcal{L}^{\prime} with Œ±‚Ä≤‚àòh‚äóm=Œ±superscriptùõº‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñétensor-productabsentùëöùõº\alpha^{\prime}\circ h^{\otimes m}=\alpha. The group structure is obvious. The relation between Dmsubscriptùê∑ùëöD_{m} and H1‚Å°(ùí≥,‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1))superscriptH1ùí≥‚Ñ§ùëö1\operatorname{H}^{1}(\mathcal{X},\mathbb{Z}/m(1)) can be easily seen in the light of Grothendieck‚Äôs descent theory; the automorphism group of the trivial element (Oùí≥,1)subscriptùëÇùí≥1(O_{\mathcal{X}},1) of Dmsubscriptùê∑ùëöD_{m} is ‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)‚Ñ§ùëö1\mathbb{Z}/m(1), just as the automorphism group of the trivial (or any) line bundle is ùîæmsubscriptùîæùëö\mathbb{G}_{m}.

The isomorphism œÜùúë\varphi may now be constructed directly. Given f‚ààùí¶ùíÆ(m)ùëìsubscriptsuperscriptùí¶ùëöùíÆf\in\mathcal{K}^{(m)}_{\mathcal{S}}, we know that the principal Oùí¶subscriptùëÇùí¶O_{\mathcal{K}}-ideal generated by fùëìf is an mùëöm-th power away from ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}, so the sheaf f‚ÄãOùí≥ùëìsubscriptùëÇùí≥fO_{\mathcal{X}} is the mùëöm-th power of a unique ideal sheaf ‚Ñê‚Ñê\mathcal{I}. This settles the case where TùëáT is replaced by the empty set.

Now we put TùëáT and ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} back in. (This is the part where our terminology and that in [De] differ the most.) We let Œ∫‚Äã(ùíØ):=‚®Åv‚ààùíØŒ∫‚Äã(v),assignùúÖùíØsubscriptdirect-sumùë£ùíØùúÖùë£\kappa(\mathcal{T}):=\bigoplus_{v\in\mathcal{T}}\kappa(v), where Œ∫‚Äã(v)ùúÖùë£\kappa(v) is the residue field at vùë£v, as usual. Now Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, a so-called trivialization at ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}, is an isomorphism

Œ≤:Œ∫‚Äã(ùíØ)‚äóOùí≥‚Ñí‚Äã‚ü∂‚àº‚ÄãŒ∫‚Äã(ùíØ),:ùõΩsubscripttensor-productsubscriptùëÇùí≥ùúÖùíØ‚Ñísimilar-to‚ü∂ùúÖùíØ\beta:\kappa(\mathcal{T})\otimes_{O_{\mathcal{X}}}\mathcal{L}\overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow}\kappa(\mathcal{T}),

which has to be compatible with Œ±ùõº\alpha in the obvious way:

i‚ÄãdŒ∫‚Äã(ùíØ)‚äóŒ±=Œ≤‚äóm.tensor-productùëñsubscriptùëëùúÖùíØùõºsuperscriptùõΩtensor-productabsentùëöid_{\kappa(\mathcal{T})}\otimes\alpha=\beta^{\otimes m}.

Two triples (‚Ñí,Œ±,Œ≤)‚ÑíùõºùõΩ(\mathcal{L},\alpha,\beta) and (‚Ñí‚Ä≤,Œ±‚Ä≤,Œ≤‚Ä≤)superscript‚Ñí‚Ä≤superscriptùõº‚Ä≤superscriptùõΩ‚Ä≤(\mathcal{L}^{\prime},\alpha^{\prime},\beta^{\prime}) as above are equivalent if there is an isomorphism h:‚Ñí‚Äã‚Üí‚àº‚Äã‚Ñí‚Ä≤:‚Ñé‚Ñísimilar-to‚Üísuperscript‚Ñí‚Ä≤h:\mathcal{L}\overset{\sim}{\to}\mathcal{L}^{\prime} such that

The above argument carries over directly to produce a canonical isomorphism between the groups ùí¶ùíÆ,T(m)/ùí¶T√ómsubscriptsuperscriptùí¶ùëöùíÆùëásuperscriptsubscriptùí¶ùëáabsentùëö{\mathcal{K}}^{(m)}_{\mathcal{S},T}/\mathcal{K}_{T}^{\times m} and DmùíØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëöùíØD_{m}^{\mathcal{T}}. It remains to identify DmùíØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëöùíØD_{m}^{\mathcal{T}} with √©tale cohomology. We feel this should be known, and it certainly can be extracted from [De] with some effort. Let us give a direct argument anyway, via Cech cohomology.

Using that m=‚ÑìŒΩùëösuperscript‚Ñìùúàm=\ell^{\nu} is invertible in Oùí≥subscriptùëÇùí≥O_{\mathcal{X}}, one easily obtains that every element of DmùíØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëöùíØD_{m}^{\mathcal{T}} is trivialized by some √©tale covering (Ui)isubscriptsubscriptùëàùëñùëñ(U_{i})_{i} of ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}. We may suppose that all UisubscriptùëàùëñU_{i} connected. The resulting transition maps over Ui‚à©UjsubscriptùëàùëñsubscriptùëàùëóU_{i}\cap U_{j} are on the one hand sections of ‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)‚Ñ§ùëö1\mathbb{Z}/m(1) (as we said, this is the automorphism sheaf of the trivial element of Dmsubscriptùê∑ùëöD_{m}), but because of the trivialisation at ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} they are all trivial whenever Ui‚à©UjsubscriptùëàùëñsubscriptùëàùëóU_{i}\cap U_{j} has a point above ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}. This produces therefore a 1-cocycle over the sheaf j!‚Äã‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1)subscriptùëó‚Ñ§ùëö1j_{!}\mathbb{Z}/m(1) relative to the covering, and hence a canonical map Œ¥ùíØsuperscriptùõøùíØ\delta^{\mathcal{T}} from DmùíØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëöùíØD_{m}^{\mathcal{T}} to the first Cech cohomology of that sheaf. Since Cech cohomology embeds into √©tale cohomology, Œ¥ùíØsuperscriptùõøùíØ\delta^{\mathcal{T}} gives a morphism DmùíØ‚ÜíH1‚Å°(ùí≥,j!‚Äã‚Ñ§/m‚Äã(1))‚Üísubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùíØùëösuperscriptH1ùí≥subscriptùëó‚Ñ§ùëö1D^{\mathcal{T}}_{m}\to\operatorname{H}^{1}(\mathcal{X},j_{!}\mathbb{Z}/m(1)). The analogous map with ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} empty is an isomorphism. One has a commutative diagram

The top sequence comes from a standard s.e.s, cf. [GPff]. One can check directly that the leftmost vertical map is the identity. Since Œ¥ùõø\delta is an isomorphism, Œ¥ùíØsuperscriptùõøùíØ\delta^{\mathcal{T}} is an isomorphism as well. This proves the proposition. Q.E.D.

Now, the proposition above together with the above mentioned identification of ‚Ñ≥‚Äã[m]‚Ñ≥delimited-[]ùëö\mathcal{M}[m] with (ùí¶ùíÆ,T(m)/ùí¶T√óm)‚àísuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùí¶ùëöùíÆùëásuperscriptsubscriptùí¶ùëáabsentùëö\left({\mathcal{K}}^{(m)}_{\mathcal{S},T}/\mathcal{K}_{T}^{\times m}\right)^{-} and a passage to the projective limit, gives a proof of Theorem 5.4. Q.E.D.

In order to use the results 5.4 and 5.3 towards our goal of identifying the Tate class in terms of T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)subscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}) we need some intermediate lemmas. All previous notation remains in place.

Lemma 5.6.

With these preparations, we can state and prove the main result of this section. Theorem 5.9.

If the assumption at the beginning of Lemma 5.7 is satisfied, then there is a canonical isomorphism in D‚Äã(‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G])ùê∑subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]ùê∫D(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G])

Proof: By Theorem 5.4 and Lemma 5.6 we have a canonical (therefore ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìequivariant) isomorphism in the derived category D‚Äã(‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G])ùê∑subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]ùê∫D(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G])

We now descend from ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} to XùëãX. From [Bu1], diagram (8) on p.371 plus comment (see also definition of C‚Äã(Œ∏)‚àôùê∂superscriptùúÉ‚àôC(\theta)^{\bullet} on p.366 of loc.¬†cit.) we get a canonical isomorphism in the derived category D‚Äã(‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G])ùê∑subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]ùê∫D(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G])

(8) R‚ÄãŒì‚Äã(X,j!‚Äã‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã(1))‚àí‚âÖC‚àô‚Äã[‚àí1].ùëÖŒìsuperscriptùëãsubscriptùëósubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñì1superscriptùê∂‚àôdelimited-[]1R\Gamma(X,j_{!}\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}(1))^{-}\cong C^{\bullet}[-1].

Three comments are necessary in order to derive this isomorphism from loc. cit.

(1) To link up with the notation in [Bu1], note that the (‚àí1)1(-1) shift of the mapping cone of the map of complexes 1‚àíŒ≥:M‚Äã[‚àí1]‚ÜíM‚Äã[‚àí1]:1ùõæ‚ÜíùëÄdelimited-[]1ùëÄdelimited-[]11-\gamma:M[-1]\to M[-1] (which is the precise definition of Burns‚Äô C‚Äã(Œ∏)‚àôùê∂superscriptùúÉ‚àôC(\theta)^{\bullet} in our context) is exactly the complex C‚àô‚Äã[‚àí1]superscriptùê∂‚àôdelimited-[]1C^{\bullet}[-1].

(2) We also remark that [Bu1] is concerned with the function field case where there is a canonical choice for Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, to wit Frobenius. But actually the isomorphism class (in the derived sense) of the complex C‚àô:[M‚Üí1‚àíŒ≥M]:superscriptùê∂‚àôdelimited-[]superscript‚Üí1ùõæùëÄùëÄC^{\bullet}:[M\stackrel{{\scriptstyle 1-\gamma}}{{\rightarrow}}M] does not change when Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is replaced by any other generator of ŒìŒì\Gamma, so the lack of a canonical generator of ŒìŒì\Gamma is not an issue.

(3) The rest of the argument taken from [Bu1] is entirely cohomological algebra, so there is no difference between the function field and number field cases in this respect.

Finally, we combine (8) with Lemma 5.8 to get the isomorphism in the statement of the above theorem.‚ÄÉQ. E. D.

Remark 5.10.

(1) If one weakens the assumption at the beginning of Lemma 5.7 to say that just CT‚Äã(K)superscriptùê∂ùëáùêæC^{T}(K) (the minus-‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-part of c‚Äãl‚Äã(K)ùëêùëôùêæcl(K)) is SùëÜS-generated (which is even closer to Hypothesis (1) in Section 2), then an ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-adic version of that lemma remains correct, as well as a version of the preceding theorem, in which the modified Tate class œÑ‚Ä≤superscriptùúè‚Ä≤\tau^{\prime} only exists as an ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell-adic object.

(2) With notations as in the proof of Lemma 5.8, one also has (‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚äó‚Ñ§œÑ)‚àí‚âÖ(C‚Ä≤‚àô)‚àísuperscriptsubscripttensor-product‚Ñ§subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìùúèsuperscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptùê∂‚Ä≤‚àô(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}}\tau)^{-}\cong({C^{\prime}}^{\bullet})^{-}. The complex C‚Ä≤‚àôsuperscriptsuperscriptùê∂‚Ä≤‚àô{C^{\prime}}^{\bullet} arises from MùëÄM by a very simple and explicit construction involving pushout along ŒπùúÑ\iota. Remark 5.11.

6. Examples

We finish this paper by sketching one or two examples, without going into detail too deeply. The main purpose is twofold: to have a certain reality check on our results, and to give the reader a feeling what is going on.

We choose a setting that is as simple as possible. Let k=‚Ñöùëò‚Ñök=\mathbb{Q} and K+superscriptùêæK^{+} the cubic field of conductor 7. We take ‚Ñì=3‚Ñì3\ell=3. For KùêæK, we will look at two choices: K=K+‚ÄãLùêæsuperscriptùêæùêøK=K^{+}L where the imaginary quadratic field LùêøL is either ‚Ñö(‚àí5\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5} or ‚Ñö‚Äã(‚àí37)‚Ñö37\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-37}). In both cases KùêæK is CM and of course kùëòk is totally real. For SùëÜS we consistently take the set of ramified primes in K/kùêæùëòK/k together with the 3-adic primes; the contribution of the places over 555 (resp.¬†37) and of the infinite places disappears in the minus part. For TùëáT we take the set of places in KùêæK above any totally split place in K/kùêæùëòK/k. In both cases, 7 is split in LùêøL and ramified in K/LùêæùêøK/L. Moreover Œ∂3subscriptùúÅ3\zeta_{3} is not contained in K‚àûsubscriptùêæK_{\infty}. Hence the ‚Äútoric part‚Äù, that is, the kernel of T‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àûT)‚ÜíT‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àû)‚Üísubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëásubscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptùê∂T_{\ell}(C^{T}_{\infty})\to T_{\ell}(C_{\infty}), is a copy of the free module ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G‚Ä≤]subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G^{\prime}], where G‚Ä≤=Gal‚Å°(K/L)=Gal‚Å°(K+/‚Ñö)superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤GalùêæùêøGalsuperscriptùêæ‚ÑöG^{\prime}=\operatorname{Gal}(K/L)=\operatorname{Gal}(K^{+}/\mathbb{Q}). The rank of the lattice ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[S‚àíS‚Ñì]‚àísubscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëÜsubscriptùëÜ‚Ñì\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[S-S_{\ell}]^{-} is 1 in both cases. Thus we have in both cases, recalling that M=T‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñ≥)ùëÄsubscriptùëá‚Ñì‚Ñ≥M=T_{\ell}(\mathcal{M}):

r‚Äãk‚Äã(M)=Œª3,K‚àí+4,ùëüùëòùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêæ4rk(M)=\lambda_{3,K}^{-}+4,

where the constant 4 comes about as 3+1313+1; 3 for the toric part and 1 for the lattice part. Since MùëÄM is free over ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äã[G‚Ä≤]subscript‚Ñ§‚Ñìdelimited-[]superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}[G^{\prime}], this already tells us that Œª3,K‚àí‚â°2superscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêæ2\lambda_{3,K}^{-}\equiv 2 modulo 3.

This can also be seen from the Kida formula which says

Œª3,K‚àí=3‚ÄãŒª3,L+2.superscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêæ3subscriptùúÜ3ùêø2\lambda_{3,K}^{-}=3\lambda_{3,L}+2.

First case: K=K+‚Äã(‚àí5)ùêæsuperscriptùêæ5K=K^{+}(\sqrt{-5}). Here 3 is split in LùêøL, and by [DFKS], Œª3,L=Œª3,L‚àí=1subscriptùúÜ3ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêø1\lambda_{3,L}=\lambda_{3,L}^{-}=1. Hence Œª3,K‚àí=5superscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêæ5\lambda_{3,K}^{-}=5 and the rank of MùëÄM is 9. Both the ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants and coinvariants of MùëÄM give a rank 2 module with trivial G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}-action.

Second case: K=K+‚Äã(‚àí37)ùêæsuperscriptùêæ37K=K^{+}(\sqrt{-37}). Here 3 is inert in LùêøL, and therefore Œª3,L=Œª3,L‚àí=0subscriptùúÜ3ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêø0\lambda_{3,L}=\lambda_{3,L}^{-}=0. Hence Œª3,K‚àí=2superscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùêæ2\lambda_{3,K}^{-}=2 and the rank of MùëÄM is 6. Both the ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants and coinvariants of MùëÄM give a rank 1 module with trivial G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}-action.

Final remark on the first case: Since the toric part has no ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants, and the lattice part of MùëÄM has rank one, it follows that the module of ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants in M0:=T‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àû)assignsubscriptùëÄ0subscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptùê∂M_{0}:=T_{\ell}(C_{\infty}) has rank one. This already excludes that the rank of M0subscriptùëÄ0M_{0} is 2, as happens in the second case. Indeed, if the rank were 2, then M0subscriptùëÄ0M_{0} would be annihilated by the norm element of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}, so M0subscriptùëÄ0M_{0} would be free over the DVR ‚Ñ§3‚Äã[G‚Ä≤]/NG‚Ä≤subscript‚Ñ§3delimited-[]superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤subscriptùëÅsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mathbb{Z}_{3}[G^{\prime}]/N_{G^{\prime}}. We know that a chosen generator Œ≥ùõæ\gamma of ŒìŒì\Gamma has an eigenvalue 1 on this module; but then the characteristic polynomial of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma would have to be (x‚àí1)2superscriptùë•12(x-1)^{2} (in other words, the eigenvalue 1 would have algebraic multiplicity 2). This would contradict the 3-adic Gross conjecture, which states that the quotient of T‚Ñì‚Äã(C‚àû)subscriptùëá‚Ñìsubscriptùê∂T_{\ell}(C_{\infty}) by its ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants has no ŒìŒì\Gamma-invariants.
